stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the final level, Course 15, focusing on a 'Mario Paint' minigame. He programmed the core painting and clearing mechanics, debugged the scoring system, and spent the majority of the stream modeling a 3D version of the Mario Paint robot NPC from scratch to act as the minigame's judge.

development_findings.summary: The game's final level, Course 15, is currently in development and will feature a retro section inspired by Mario Paint.
Kaze implemented a custom fill tool algorithm because a standard recursive approach would cause a stack overflow on the N64. His solution uses a block of temporary memory as a manual stack.
development_findings.quote: Remember there's a recursive function. Yeah, but the stack is not big enough for that. So I can't do that... So I had to invent something.

development_findings.summary: A conscious design decision was made to exclude an 'undo' feature from the painting minigame, only providing a full reset to maintain a sense of stakes.
development_findings.quote: I don't want to store an undo thing... It's still a game, guys. This is not an image editor. You fuck up, you lose your points.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discussed a deep technical aspect of the N64 hardware: a 'hidden' megabyte of memory accessible through the 9th bit of every byte, which is normally used for triangle rendering coverage.
development_findings.quote: The Nintendo 64 has around one megabyte of hidden memory that you don't really use... secretly, all the bytes on the N64 are nine bits.

development_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrated expert knowledge of the N64's rendering pipeline, explaining why T-junctions in his 3D model are not an issue due to the console's fixed-point math and his world-axis-aligned geometry.
development_findings.quote: N64 is fixed points. And these are world axis aligned. Which means that the rounding arrow there will always be 0. And there can't possibly be a seam.

development_findings.summary: He is willing to use a relatively high polygon count for models in small, isolated sub-areas where performance is guaranteed to be high, allowing for more faithful sprite-to-3D adaptations.
development_findings.quote: This is comically high poly, but that's fine because it's such a small sub area.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant part of the stream creating a 3D model of the Mario Paint robot from scratch in Blender to serve as the judge for the painting minigame.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prefers open-world exploration and the 'journey between dungeons' over the dungeons themselves, citing this as why he loves Majora's Mask and is hesitant about Skyward Sword.
context_findings.quote: what I like in Zelda games is all the open world and exploration and not really the dungeons.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the political climate has shifted significantly since 2016, making it impossible to create political meme hacks today without them being interpreted as serious, inflammatory statements.
context_findings.quote: if I do the same thing in 2024 with the Trump 64 ROM hack, people will murder me. So I can't do it, I think.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a desire to evolve as a creator and move on from his past work, rather than repeating successful formulas.
context_findings.quote: I have to move on. You cannot redo a hundred times what you've done in the past.

context_findings.summary: Kaze receives paid sponsorships for streaming, such as an upcoming one from Roblox, which is a part of his income as a creator.
context_findings.quote: they're paying me money to stream Roblox, like I'd be stupid not to take that

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering turning the project into a commercial indie game after completion by replacing Nintendo's IP, but acknowledges he would need to consult a lawyer.
context_findings.quote: there is this idea of maybe asset swapping Return to Yoshi's Island when it's done and releasing it under my own IP, because the only vanilla actor I use in this game is Mario himself

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, are currently playing The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess together in their personal time.

key_stories.title: The Fill Tool Stack Overflow Problem
key_stories.summary: Faced with the N64's limited stack size preventing a standard recursive fill algorithm, Kaze created a custom solution. He used a block of temporary memory as a manual stack to process pixels, successfully implementing the feature without causing a crash.
key_stories.challenge: A standard recursive 'paint bucket' fill algorithm would overflow the N64's limited stack, making it unusable for the Mario Paint minigame.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the N64's stack limitation as a blocker. He designed an alternative solution where he allocated temporary memory to serve as a custom stack for pixels needing to be checked, effectively creating his own fill logic from scratch.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a performant fill tool by creating a non-recursive algorithm that uses a manually managed block of temporary memory as a pixel stack, circumventing the hardware's limitations.
key_stories.key_quote: The stack is not big enough for that. So I can't do that. It requires a function like that will just underflow the stack. So I had to invent something.

key_stories.title: Choosing the Painting Judge
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed an NPC to judge the player's painting. After rejecting the 'Undo Dog' to avoid promising a non-existent undo feature, he took suggestions from his community and settled on the Save Robot from Mario Paint, which he then modeled in 3D.
key_stories.challenge: The painting minigame required an NPC to act as a judge, but Kaze, being unfamiliar with Mario Paint, needed to find a suitable character.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially considered the 'Undo Dog' but rejected it to avoid creating false expectations about an undo feature. He solicited ideas from his stream chat, who suggested the Save Robot. Agreeing it was a perfect fit, he then undertook the process of modeling it.
key_stories.outcome: The Save Robot from Mario Paint/Super Mario Maker was chosen. Kaze found a sprite reference online and created a 3D model of the character from scratch during the stream to serve as the NPC judge.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm a little bit scared that the Undo Dog will make people think that they can undo. And I will absolutely not add undo to this.

key_stories.title: The T-Junction Debate
key_stories.summary: A viewer criticized Kaze's 3D modeling for using T-junctions. Kaze used it as a teaching moment, explaining that while this is an issue in modern engines, the N64's fixed-point math and his axis-aligned model prevent the typical rendering artifacts, showcasing his expert knowledge of the hardware.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer criticized Kaze's 3D modeling for using T-junctions, suggesting they would cause rendering artifacts.
key_stories.process: Kaze paused his work to address the viewer's concern directly. He provided a detailed technical explanation of why T-junctions are problematic in modern engines (due to floating-point inaccuracies) but are perfectly safe on the N64 when using fixed-point math and axis-aligned polygons.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze confidently kept his model as is, having correctly identified that the potential issue does not apply to the N64's specific rendering architecture in this context.
key_stories.key_quote: N64 is fixed points. And these are world axis aligned. Which means that the rounding arrow there will always be 0. And there can't possibly be a seam. You think I didn't think of that?
